Chapter 2.43

November 1437, Evening

You stand at the window of your private chambers in the Aljafería Palace, looking out over the darkened gardens below. The cool November air carries the faint scent of the Ebro—river-mud and autumn leaves. Behind you, on the great oak table, lie the drafts of three new Books for the Fueros de Aragón: the registry of privileges, the sacred tithe, the voluntary muster. Three days of negotiations distilled into ink and parchment.

Diego de Daza sits in the corner, still reviewing the financial provisions with meticulous care. Isaac de Baeza departed an hour ago to his own quarters, his work done for now. Somewhere in the women's wing, Queen María—Alfonso's widow, soon to be aunt to your realm—rests after helping you navigate the treacherous waters of Aragonese politics.

Tomorrow the Cortes reconvenes. Tomorrow you will stand before the assembled estates—clergy, nobility, cities—and swear the coronation oath. The words have been written for centuries: "We who are as good as you swear to you who are no better than we, to accept you as our King and Sovereign Lord, provided you observe all our liberties and laws; but if not, not." A contract, not a coronation. A negotiation made permanent.

The Archbishop has agreed to the tercias. The nobles have accepted the registry—with conditions, but accepted nonetheless. Even the merchants, after your stumble and recovery, have expressed willingness to listen further. By the standards of Aragonese succession, this is triumph. Yet in Toledo, Lucia grows heavier with your third child, and you will not be there when the moment comes.

Diego looks up from his documents. "The provisions are sound, Your Majesty. The thirty-day grace period for oath violation accusations—that was a wise addition. It protects both sides."

The ceremony would take place in La Seo (the Cathedral of San Salvador) in Zaragoza, which was the traditional coronation site for Aragonese kings. I should include appropriate Latin phrases and medieval Aragonese customs.

The morning of your coronation dawns gray and cold, a thin mist rising from the Ebro to shroud the towers of La Seo. The Cathedral of San Salvador has witnessed the making of Aragonese kings for centuries—its stones remember oaths kept and broken, dynasties risen and fallen. Today it will witness you.

You dress in the robes prepared for this moment: cloth-of-gold over crimson, the arms of Castile quartered now with those of Aragón. No crown yet—that comes after the oath, if the oath is accepted. In Aragón, a king earns his crown by contract.

The procession moves through streets lined with watching crowds. Not the wild enthusiasm of Granada's liberation, but something more measured—Aragonese reserve, judgment suspended until the oath is sworn. They have seen kings before. They will see if this one proves different.

Inside La Seo, the three estates have assembled in their ancient order. The clergy fill the choir stalls, Archbishop Dalmau de Mur resplendent in his vestments at the high altar. The nobility occupies the right side of the nave—you see Don Lope Ximénez de Urrea in the place of honor, his lined face unreadable, and beside him Don Juan de Híjar with arms crossed and jaw set. Don Bernat de Centelles catches your eye and nods almost imperceptibly. The merchants and city representatives fill the left side, Berenguer de Montcada at their head, his expression careful.

The Justicia of Aragón, Don Martín Díez de Aux, stands between the estates and the altar. It is he, not the Archbishop, who will administer the oath. In Aragón, the law stands above even holy unction.

You walk the long nave alone. No attendants, no guards—another Aragonese tradition. A king comes to his people as a man seeking a contract, not a conqueror demanding submission.

At the altar, you kneel.

The Justicia's voice rings through the cathedral, speaking the ancient formula in the old Aragonese tongue: "Nos, que valemos tanto como vos, os hacemos nuestro Rey y Señor, con tal que guardéis nuestros fueros y libertades; y si no, no."

We, who are as good as you, make you our King and Sovereign Lord, provided you observe our fueros and liberties; and if not, not.

The cathedral falls utterly silent. Every eye fixes upon you.

You speak the response—the words you studied with María, the oath you have prepared yourself to keep: You swear to maintain the fueros entire and inviolate. You swear to preserve the liberties of the estates. You swear to submit to the Justicia's judgment in matters of law. You swear, and your voice carries clear and steady through the ancient stones.

The Justicia nods. "The oath is given. Let the estates respond."

Archbishop Dalmau speaks first, as tradition demands. But his words go beyond the formal acceptance. He speaks of a king who came to Aragón not with demands but with questions. Who read the fueros before swearing them. Who proposed strengthening Aragonese liberties rather than circumventing them. "The Church accepts this oath," he concludes, "and rejoices in it."

Then Don Lope Ximénez de Urrea rises from his seat.

The old man moves slowly, arthritis evident in every step, but the cathedral hangs on his motion. Sixty years he has negotiated with Aragonese kings. Four monarchs have learned to respect—or fear—his stubborn defense of noble privilege. When Don Lope speaks, Aragón listens.

"I have seen kings swear this oath," he says, his voice carrying despite its age. "I have seen them swear it with fingers crossed behind their backs. I have seen them swear it while their lawyers sought loopholes. I have seen them swear it and break it within the year."

He pauses, and in that pause you feel the weight of Aragonese history—centuries of struggle between crown and constitution, between royal ambition and noble liberty.

"This king," Don Lope continues, "came to us differently. When we demanded conditions, he did not argue—he improved upon them. When we asked for guarantees, he offered stronger ones than we had thought to request. When we tested him with the Justicia, he declared that reforms to that office must come from us, not from him."

The old man's eyes find yours across the cathedral.

"I have negotiated with four kings of Aragón. This is the first I have believed."

He turns to the assembled nobility. "The nobility accepts this oath. Not merely in form, but in substance. Not merely today, but in hope of what may follow."

A murmur runs through the noble ranks—surprise, consideration, and then, from Don Bernat and others, voices rising in agreement. Even Don Juan de Híjar, whatever his private feelings, does not dissent aloud. Don Lope has spoken. To contradict him publicly would be to break noble unity.

Berenguer de Montcada rises for the merchants. His words are more cautious—the wound of your earlier misstep has not fully healed—but he acknowledges what has been seen. "The cities have watched these negotiations," he says. "We have seen a king who, when he erred, admitted error. Who, when we refused, did not threaten. Who spoke of partnership rather than subjection." He pauses. "The cities accept this oath, and await the partnership we have been promised."

Archbishop Dalmau lifts the crown of Aragón—simpler than Castile's, iron rather than gold, a reminder of the kingdom's martial origins—and speaks the blessing. Holy oil touches your forehead. The weight of iron settles onto your brow.

"Vivat Rex! Vivat Rex! Vivat Rex!"

The acclamation erupts not in the cold formality you expected, but with genuine voice. Cheers echo from the stone vaults. You see men who entered this cathedral suspicious now shouting with something approaching enthusiasm. Not the wild love of subjects for a conqueror, but something perhaps more valuable—the respect of free men for a king who has shown he understands what freedom means to them.

As you rise, crowned, you catch fragments of conversation from the noble ranks: "—studied the fueros before he swore—" and "—apologized to the merchants, can you imagine Alfonso—" and "—refused to touch the Justicia, said it must come from us—"

The stories have spread. Your conduct in the negotiations has become known. And in Aragón, where kings are judged not by their power but by their respect for limits, these stories matter more than any military victory.

Outside La Seo, the crowds have heard the acclamation. As you emerge into the gray November light, King of Aragón as well as Castile, the cheering spreads through the streets of Zaragoza. Church bells begin to ring—first La Seo, then San Pablo, then others across the city.

Don Lope appears at your side, moving with difficulty but determined. "You have made a good beginning, Your Majesty," he says quietly, beneath the noise. "Now you must keep what you have sworn. We will be watching."

It is, you realize, the highest compliment an Aragonese noble can pay.

Queen María waits at the cathedral steps, her face showing something you haven't seen there before—genuine hope. She has watched one husband neglect this kingdom for Italian dreams. Perhaps she dares to believe this one will prove different.

You are Juan II, by the grace of God King of Castile, León, and now Aragón. Three crowns. Three oaths. Three sets of expectations.

In Toledo, Lucia carries your third child. In Naples, barons await your pleasure. In Constantinople, allies prepare for a war that will shake the world.

But here, now, in Zaragoza, the bells ring for a king who listened.

The Liberator Comes

You depart Barcelona in early December with your household guard and such knights as chose to accompany you—perhaps two hundred men, enough for dignity without stripping Aragón of defenders. The Catalan shipwrights provide three war galleys and four transport vessels, their masters eager to cement favor with the new king who speaks of Mediterranean partnerships rather than Castilian dominance.

The winter crossing should be treacherous. It is not.

The winds blow from the northwest—unseasonable, the sailors murmur, providential. What should take three weeks takes twelve days. The seas that swallowed fleets in Decembers past lie calm as a millpond. Old sailors make the sign of the cross and speak of Saint Elmo's favor.

On the seventh day, off the coast of Sardinia, sails appear on the horizon.

Your captains call for battle stations—Angevin raiders, perhaps, or Genoese opportunists. But as the vessels draw closer, the lookouts call down in confusion: "Aragonese colors! No—Neapolitan! They're flying the arms of Naples!"

A delegation. Six Neapolitan war galleys, their oars flashing in winter sunlight, have sailed out to meet you. At their head flies the banner of the Caracciolo—one of Naples' most powerful baronial families.

The lead galley draws alongside. A man in his fifties, armor polished to mirror brightness, calls across the water in accented but serviceable Castilian:

"Your Majesty! I am Sergianni Caracciolo, Duke of Venosa, come to escort il Liberatore to his kingdom! René of Anjou fled Naples three days past—his supporters scatter like rats from a sinking ship. The barons have prepared a reception such as Naples has not seen since the days of the first Alfonso!"

The Neapolitan galleys fall into formation around your small fleet—an honor guard that swells your seven vessels to thirteen. As you round the cape and the Bay of Naples opens before you, more ships emerge from the harbor. Twenty. Thirty. The entire Neapolitan fleet, such as it remains after Alfonso's wars, has sortied to welcome its new king.

And beyond the ships—Naples itself.

The city rises from the bay in tiers of white and gold, dominated by the massive bulk of Castel Nuovo, the Angevin fortress that now awaits an Aragonese—a Castilian—a Trastámara master. Smoke rises from a thousand chimneys. Church bells ring across the water, their sound carrying for miles in the still winter air.

As your galley enters the harbor, you see the quays black with people. Not the cautious reserve of Zaragoza, not the measured judgment of Aragón. This is something else entirely—desperate hope given form. Naples has suffered under Angevin misrule, under baronial warfare, under the chaos of disputed succession. The lords who declared for you did so not from love, but from calculation: you are the strong hand they need, the king who conquered Granada, the ruler who might finally bring order to their fractured realm.

But the common people of Naples have heard other stories. Stories of a king who treats his subjects justly. Who rebuilt a conquered kingdom rather than plundering it. Who kept faith with former enemies. Whether these stories are fully accurate matters less than what they represent: hope.

"Il Liberatore! Il Liberatore!"

The cry begins at the docks and spreads through the city like fire. By the time your galley touches the quay, all of Naples seems to be shouting it.

A delegation of barons waits on the dock—the great names of the kingdom assembled in unprecedented unity. You recognize some from reports: Giovanni Antonio Orsini, Prince of Taranto, the most powerful lord in the realm. Raimondo del Balzo, Duke of Andria. Francesco Sforza's representative, watching with calculating eyes on behalf of Milan's interests. And Sergianni Caracciolo himself, having raced ahead to take his place among the welcoming party.

The Prince of Taranto steps forward as you descend the gangplank. He is a large man, running to fat, but his eyes are sharp and his bow is deep.

"Your Majesty," he says, in Italian that your years of study allow you to follow. "Naples has waited long for a king worthy of her. René of Anjou proved... inadequate. His supporters have fled or submitted. The throne of Sicily citra Pharum stands empty, awaiting its rightful lord."

He gestures toward Castel Nuovo, looming above the harbor.

"The castle is prepared. The coronation regalia has been retrieved from where René's people hid it. The Archbishop of Naples awaits to perform the unction." A pause, weighted with meaning. "All that remains is for Your Majesty to state the terms upon which you will rule us."

The other barons watch. This is the moment—not the ceremony, not the crown, but this. Naples has declared for you, yes. But Naples is a kingdom of powerful lords who have made and unmade kings for generations. They have chosen you because they believe you will serve their interests.

Naples operated under a unique feudal system where papal authority and baronial power significantly constrained the monarch. The king nominally held the kingdom as a papal fief, requiring formal investiture and tribute. While the crown possessed theoretical administrative powers like taxation and judicial authority, baronial autonomy often rendered these rights more symbolic than practical. Compared to Aragon's decentralized governance, Neapolitan royal power appeared more concentrated but was effectively limited by powerful noble interests.

The royal domain included extensive lands, yet feudal obligations remained complex and inconsistently enforced. Unlike Aragon's robust parliamentary system, Naples had a weaker legislative body with minimal capacity to challenge royal decrees.

The reception is warm, yes—the barons have chosen you over any potential Angevin resurgence, and your reputation precedes you. But this is a succession, not a liberation. Alfonso ruled here. These men knew him, served him, negotiated with him. Now they take the measure of his successor.

At your question, Diego's brow furrows. He speaks quietly, for your ears alone.

"Your Majesty, I must confess my knowledge of Neapolitan governance is... limited. I am a Castilian administrator. What I know comes from reports and correspondence, not direct experience."

He glances toward the waiting barons.

"But the broad strokes: Naples is not Aragón. There are no fueros here, no Justicia with power to void royal decrees. In theory, the crown's authority is far more direct." He pauses. "In theory."

"The difficulty is twofold. First, Naples is a papal fief. The king holds the realm from the Holy Father and owes tribute and fealty to Rome. Pope Eugenius invested your cousin Alfonso after his conquest—you will need similar investiture, though given your relationship with the Holy See, this should not prove difficult."

"Second..." Diego lowers his voice further. "The barons. They have no constitutional limits on royal power because they do not need them. They simply are the power in much of the kingdom. Their lands, their castles, their private armies. Alfonso spent years trying to bring them to heel. He succeeded in some measure, but..."

He shakes his head.

"I would recommend Your Majesty speak with those who know this kingdom better. Queen María knew Alfonso's struggles here. And perhaps—" he gestures toward the delegation, "—one of these lords might speak frankly, if asked the right questions."

The Prince of Taranto's expression flickers—surprise, perhaps, or reassessment. New kings typically save such questions for private councils, not dockside conversations within earshot of half the nobility of Naples. But he recovers smoothly, gesturing for you to walk with him toward the waiting horses.

"Your Majesty asks directly," he says, falling into step beside you. His Italian is slower now, accommodating your comprehension. "I appreciate directness. Your cousin Alfonso appreciated it less."

He waves a hand at the city rising above the harbor.

"The crown's rights in Naples are... extensive in theory. This is not Aragón, where kings must beg permission to collect their own revenues. Here, the king rules by right. No Justicia countermands him. No Cortes blocks his taxes." A slight smile. "On parchment, you are nearly absolute."

"The revenues—" He pauses to help you mount the horse that has been prepared, a fine destrier in the Aragonese style. Once you are both mounted, he continues.

"The focatico—the hearth tax—is the foundation. Every household in the kingdom owes the crown a fixed sum annually. In principle, this should yield perhaps 200,000 ducats." He stresses the word should meaningfully. "Then customs duties on the ports—Naples, Gaeta, Salerno, others. The salt monopoly. Judicial revenues. Rights of escheat. In a well-ordered kingdom, the crown of Naples might collect 400,000 ducats annually. Perhaps more."

THE PORTRAIT

Intelligence: 72 — Sharp

Nicolás possesses a keen, practical mind. He will never match his half-brother Fernando's scholarly brilliance or his half-sister Catalina's extraordinary intellect, but he grasps situations quickly, learns from experience, and understands men. His intelligence is the intelligence of the field commander—rapid assessment, clear decision, efficient action.

He will not write treatises or debate theologians. But he will read a battlefield in a glance, understand an enemy's intentions from the disposition of their forces, and know when to press an advantage and when to withdraw. His mind serves his body, not the other way around.

Temperament: 74 — Commanding

There is something in Nicolás that makes men obey.

Not the magnetic, almost supernatural draw of his sister Juana. Not the assumed authority of Catalina. Something rougher, more martial—the natural command of a man born to lead soldiers. When Nicolás speaks, men listen. When he gives orders, men follow. It is not charisma; it is presence. The unmistakable quality of a leader.

Even as a child, this will manifest. Other boys will fall into line behind him without being asked. Servants will jump to his commands. Training masters will note that the young prince organizes the other squires instinctively, placing them where they should be, correcting their stances, directing their efforts.

He is born to command armies.

Martial Aptitude: 99 — Legendary

Here is the gift that defines him.

Nicolás takes to arms as naturally as breathing. The sword feels like an extension of his hand. The lance finds its target without conscious thought. On horseback, in the lists, on foot with blade and shield—it does not matter. He excels. He dominates.

By twelve, he will unhorse squires twice his age. By sixteen, he will be the finest blade in Castile. By twenty, songs will be sung of his prowess. He is El Cid reborn, the warrior prince that legends are made of, the kind of fighter who appears once in a generation and reshapes the battlefield by his mere presence.

This is not merely skill, though skill he has in abundance. It is instinct. He knows where the enemy's blade will fall before it moves. He feels the rhythm of combat like music. Violence is his native language, and he speaks it with terrible fluency.

In an age of gunpowder and changing warfare, Nicolás is a throwback—a champion of single combat, a leader who fights at the front of his men, a prince whose personal valor will inspire armies to impossible feats.

The cruelest irony of the House of Trastámara: the heir Fernando has a warrior's body and a scholar's soul. The spare Nicolás has both body and soul of a warrior born.

Special Talent: 2 — None Particular

Beyond his martial gifts, Nicolás is... ordinary.

He has no ear for languages—he will struggle with Latin and never master Greek. He has no head for administration—ledgers bore him and logistics confuse him. He has no talent for diplomacy—he says what he means and means what he says, which is admirable but not subtle. He cannot sing, cannot paint, cannot compose verse.

He is a sword. A magnificent sword, the finest sword in Christendom perhaps—but only a sword.

This limitation will shape his life. He will need others to handle the tasks he cannot: brothers to negotiate treaties, sisters to charm foreign courts, advisors to manage his accounts. Alone, he can conquer. He cannot govern.

But then, he is a second son. Governing is Fernando's burden, not his.

Piety: 73 — Devout

Nicolás believes.

He will pray before battle—genuinely, not for show. He will attend Mass with attention, take communion with reverence, confess his sins with honesty. His faith is the faith of the miles Christi, the soldier of Christ: uncomplicated, unshakeable, expressed through deeds rather than words.

When he kills enemies of the Faith—Moors, Turks, heretics—he will do so with clean conscience, believing himself an instrument of divine will. This is both his strength and his danger. A devout warrior is formidable. A devout warrior who believes God endorses his violence is terrifying.

Physical Presence: 88 — Magnificent

The second son looks the part even more than the first.

Nicolás grows tall, broad-shouldered, thick with muscle. His mother's dark Italian coloring combines with his father's strong features to create something striking—a face that belongs on coins, a body that belongs in armor. When he enters a room in full harness, men's breath catches. When he rides at the head of a column, he looks like a king.

More than Fernando, who has the build of a warrior but the bearing of a scholar, Nicolás moves like a fighter. There is economy in his gestures, coiled readiness in his stance, the unconscious grace of a predator. Women will swoon. Men will envy. Enemies will fear.

He is what a prince should look like, what a champion should look like, what a king should look like.

But he is the second son.

THE IRONY

God has a sense of humor, it seems.

Fernando, Prince of Asturias, heir to three crowns, has a magnificent body housing a scholar's soul. He looks like a warrior-king and cannot fight. His hands, made for gripping a war-sword, prefer to turn pages.

Nicolás, second son, spare heir, has been given everything Fernando lacks. The legendary martial prowess. The commanding presence. The warrior's instinct. He is everything a medieval king should be—except he will never be king.

This could be a blessing. Fernando rules, Nicolás fights. The brilliant diplomat-king and his legendary warrior-brother, each doing what God made them to do. A partnership that could reshape Europe.

Or it could be a curse. What happens when the second son is so obviously superior to the first in all the ways that medieval men value? When soldiers would rather follow Nicolás than Fernando? When nobles whisper that the wrong brother wears the crown?

History is littered with second sons who should have been first. Some served faithfully. Some rebelled. Some were quietly murdered by nervous elder brothers.

Nicolás is weeks old, sleeping in his mother's arms. But the shape of future conflict—or future glory—is already written in his stars.
